qas.question: What tool was used to improve sound quality in early recordings for special effects?
Where were loud instruments best placed for good sound quality?

answers.text: farthest away from the collecting horn

qas.question: How far away has a trumpeter been known to stand?
Were drums heard on early jazz recordings?
What was the item called that recorded the sounds?

context: Contrary to popular belief, if placed properly and prepared-for, <a3_0>drums could be effectively used<a3_0/> and heard on even the earliest jazz and military band recordings. The loudest instruments such as the drums and trumpets were positioned the <a1_0>farthest away from the <a4_0>collecting horn<a4_0/><a1_0/>. Lillian Hardin Armstrong, a member of King Oliver's Creole Jazz Band, which recorded at Gennett Records in 1923, remembered that at first Oliver and his young second trumpet, Louis Armstrong, stood next to each other and Oliver's horn could not be heard. "They put Louis about <a2_0>fifteen feet<a2_0/> over in the corner, looking all sad." For fading instrumental parts in and out while recording, some performers were placed on a <a0_0>moveable platform<a0_0/>, which could draw the performer(s) nearer or further away as required.[citation needed]
